Cover\nDirector\n The AI-native operating system and forward-deployed backbone for nonprofits\nTurning under-resourced founders into fundable, operationally tight organizations\n\n\ndirectorforgood.org\n\n\n[Your Name], Founder &amp; CEO\n\n\n\n2. Problem – Founders Are the Whole Leadership Team\nNonprofit founders are carrying 5 jobs on 1 salary.\nThey’re expected to:\nLead programs and vision\n\n\nRaise money (major gifts, grants, events)\n\n\nRun operations and finance\n\n\nOwn communications and storytelling\n\n\nManage staff, boards, and compliance\n\n\nWhen funding tightens and staff are cut, all of this collapses back onto one person.\n Promising orgs plateau at $300–600k or quietly shut down — not for lack of impact, but for lack of backbone.\n\n3. Problem – Downshifted Orgs (Beachhead)\nOur initial focus: orgs that already proved they can raise $400k–$1M.\nThese orgs:\n\n\nHave real donor and community relationships\n\n\nHave a history of 7-figure budgets or close\n\n\nBut in the current funding environment:\n\n\nThey’ve laid off staff\n\n\nThe founder is back to doing everything\n\n\nMany are considering shutting down despite strong demand for their work\n\n\nThis hits founders of color especially hard, as equity-era funding retrenches and flexible money disappears.\n\n\nThese leaders don’t need another tool. They need a backbone.\n\n4. Broken Options\nExisting solutions don’t fit this stage.\nDIY SaaS stack\n\n\nCRMs, grant tools, accounting, email…\n\n\nFounders don’t have time (or staff) to integrate and maintain them.\n\n\nConsultants &amp; agencies\n\n\nProject-based, expensive, and seen as “overhead.”\n\n\nAdvice without ongoing operational responsibility.\n\n\nRebuilding staff\n\n\nBay Area-ish:\n\n\nED: $100–150k\n\n\nOps/Finance: ~100k\n\n\nDevelopment: ~100k\n\n\nComms/Program ops: 60–100k\n\n\n$360–450k/year just for the backbone on a fragile budget.\n\n\nThere is no integrated, AI-native backbone designed for $400k–$1M orgs that have real relationships but no team.\n\n5. Director – What We Are\nDirector is an AI-native backbone and forward-deployed team for nonprofits.\nWe provide:\nDirector OS – a vertical operating system for:\n\n\nRevenue &amp; relationships\n\n\nRunway &amp; finance\n\n\nOps &amp; compliance\n\n\nBoard &amp; funder narratives\n\n\nA Director Pod – shared leadership capacity:\n\n\nForward-Deployed Director (FDD)\n\n\nFinance/ops leadership\n\n\nLater: dedicated development &amp; ops roles as we scale\n\n\nWe plug into an existing org and donor base and give them the leadership bench they can’t afford to rebuild alone.\n\n6. Fundraising Philosophy – Relationships First\nDirector is built around major gifts and real relationships, not grant roulette.\nDurable funding comes from:\n\n\nMajor donors\n\n\nAnchor institutions\n\n\nLong-term partners\n\n\nGrants are part of the picture, but:\n\n\nThey are downstream of relationships\n\n\n“Open call” grant-chasing is mostly a distraction for this segment\n\n\nDirector’s focus:\n\n\nMap and grow the major gifts pipeline\n\n\nPrepare founders for high-stakes meetings\n\n\nUse grants strategically once relationships exist\n\n\nDirector is a relationship and revenue engine, not a shot-in-the-dark grant factory.\n\n7. The Director Pod – Capacity Ramp (Lean First, Then Scale)\nPods scale from 4 → 8 → 16 orgs as the OS and agents mature.\nYear 1 – Lean “Proto-Pod”\nTeam:\n\n\nYou (Founder/CEO)\n\n\n1 Forward-Deployed Director (FDD)\n\n\n1 Finance Director (covering finance + ops)\n\n\n1 Founding Engineer\n\n\nCapacity:\n\n\nFDD deeply embedded with up to 4 orgs\n\n\nFinance Director builds cross-org finance/ops playbooks and workflows\n\n\nEngineer builds Director OS + first agents alongside you\n\n\nPhase 2 – 8 orgs\nMature core agents take on most repetitive finance/ops/reporting tasks\n\n\nSame FDD + Finance Director structure supports more orgs, with additional FDD capacity added as needed\n\n\nPhase 3 – 16 orgs\n2+ FDDs each focused on 4–6 orgs\n\n\nFinance/ops/development leadership scaled across all 16 using agents and standardized playbooks\n\n\nAgents perform the recurring work; Pods focus on relationships and decisions.\n\n8. Director OS – Product Overview\nOne pane of glass for an org’s backbone.\nDirector OS brings together:\nRevenue &amp; Relationships\n\n\nMajor gifts map and warm funder pipeline\n\n\nNext-best actions for key relationships\n\n\nRunway &amp; Finance\n\n\nLive cash forecasts and scenarios\n\n\nBudget vs. actuals visibility\n\n\nOps &amp; Compliance\n\n\nRecurring task engine (payroll, filings, renewals)\n\n\nChecklists and playbooks\n\n\nNarratives &amp; Reporting\n\n\nBoard decks and updates\n\n\nFunder reports and impact one-pagers\n\n\nData flows in from email, calendar, finance systems, docs, and existing CRMs so the OS reflects reality, not just what someone remembered to log.\n\n9. AI Agents – How We 2–4x Human Capacity\nSpecialized agents do the repetitive work; humans do the judgment.\nExamples:\nMajor Gifts Agent\n\n\nScans email, calendar, CRM for each org\n\n\nMaintains relationship maps\n\n\nSuggests outreach and drafts donor emails and meeting briefs\n\n\nFinance &amp; Runway Agent\n\n\nPulls accounting and bank data\n\n\nProposes categorizations, reconciliations, cash-flow updates\n\n\nRaises alerts on anomalies and runway risks\n\n\nOps &amp; Compliance Agent\n\n\nRuns recurring checklists (payroll, filings, renewals)\n\n\nGenerates drafts, reminders, and task lists\n\n\nBoard &amp; Reporting Agent\n\n\nAssembles board decks and funder reports from live data\n\n\nKeeps a “board-ready” view up to date\n\n\nPattern:\nAgents explore, compile, and draft.\n FDDs and Directors review, edit, and decide.\nThis is the same shift we’re seeing in engineering (Cursor/Devin-style agents) and customer ops — we’re applying it to nonprofit backbones.\n\n10. Economics – Why This Makes Sense\nDirector makes a serious backbone affordable and scalable.\nIllustrative comparison for a ~$500–700k org:\nRebuilding the traditional backbone:\n\n\nED: $100–150k\n\n\nOps/Finance: ~100k\n\n\nDev: ~100k\n\n\nComms/Program ops: 60–100k\n\n\nTotal backbone: $360–450k/year\n\n\nWith Director:\n\n\nED/founder: $100–150k\n\n\nDirector Pod (Year 1 pricing for early orgs): target ~$80–120k/year\n\n\nTotal backbone: $180–270k/year\n\n\nAs Pods scale from 4 → 8 → 16 orgs and agents automate more of the workflows:\nPod-level gross margins expand\n\n\nPer-org economics improve while keeping human leadership involvement high\n\n\n\n11. Why Now – AI Agents + Nonprofit Pressure\nTwo timing curves are intersecting.\nAgentic AI is production-ready.\n\n\n“AI coworkers” are already shipping in engineering, finance, and customer operations.\n\n\nA small human team can now manage far more complexity with agents doing most of the clicking.\n\n\nNonprofits are under structural pressure.\n\n\nOrgs that once had $1M+ budgets are losing staff and struggling to maintain operations and reporting.\n\n\nFunders are more selective and want grantees with credible backbones and visibility.\n\n\nDirector sits at this intersection:\n an AI-native backbone delivered by a lean, forward-deployed team to orgs that cannot justify rebuilding full in-house leadership.\n\n12. Go-to-Market\nWe start where we already have pull.\nExisting relationships\n\n\nFirst 2–4 orgs from founders and orgs you’re already effectively “directing.”\n\n\nDownshifted $1M orgs\n\n\nTarget leaders who have proved they can raise $400k–$1M but had to cut backbone staff.\n\n\nFunder collaborations\n\n\nPosition Director as a capacity-building line item that makes grantees more investable and easier to monitor.\n\n\nSales motion:\nShort diagnostic: map “today vs with Director” team and budget.\n\n\nDemo Director OS + agents and show what gets taken off the founder’s plate.\n\n\nClose annual retainers, expand the number of orgs and scope over time.\n\n\n\n13. Business Model &amp; QSBS-Friendly Structure\nAI-native vertical SaaS with embedded forward-deployed team.\nRevenue model\n\n\nAnnual retainers per org, tied to budget band and complexity\n\n\nLong-term goal: multiple Pods, each supporting up to 16 orgs on the OS\n\n\nCost structure\n\n\nLean Pods (FDD + Finance Director) supported by agents and product\n\n\nFounder &amp; Engineer drive product/agent development that compounds across all clients\n\n\nQSBS-aware design\n\n\nU.S. C-corp, building an active, product-centric operating business\n\n\nAssets are primarily software, data models, and operating infrastructure\n\n\nCompany is structured so founders and early investors can potentially access QSBS benefits (subject to their own tax advice)\n\n\n\n14. Team – Lean Year-1 Plan\nSmall, high-leverage founding team with 12 months of runway.\nFounder &amp; CEO (you)\n\n\nProduct vision, sales, fundraising, relationships\n\n\nActs as early FDD alongside hire as needed\n\n\nForward-Deployed Director (hire #1)\n\n\nDeep nonprofit ops + fundraising\n\n\nEmbedded across the first ~4 orgs\n\n\nFinance Director (hire #2)\n\n\nCovers finance + ops across the initial pod\n\n\nDesigns playbooks the agents will run\n\n\nFounding Engineer (hire #3)\n\n\nBuilds Director OS and the first wave of agents with you\n\n\nTarget raise for ~12 months runway (illustrative):\nLean team + non-people costs → roughly $800k–$1M\n\n\nEarly org retainers reduce net burn as you ramp to 4 paying customers.\n\n\n\n15. Roadmap &amp; Ask\nRoadmap\n0–12 months (this raise):\n\n\nHire FDD, Finance Director, Founding Engineer\n\n\nOnboard 2–4 orgs\n\n\nShip v1 Director OS and core agents (finance, ops, reporting, major gifts support)\n\n\nProve: 4-org pod with agents delivers clear revenue and stability lift\n\n\n12–24 months:\n\n\nScale pod to 8 orgs\n\n\nHarden agents and playbooks\n\n\nAdd additional FDD/finance/ops capacity as revenues justify\n\n\n24+ months:\n\n\n16-org pods on mature OS\n\n\nMultiple pods focused on key verticals (arts, youth, community, etc.)\n\n\nAsk\nRaise $800k–$1.0M to:\n\n\nFund 12+ months of lean team and product development\n\n\nProve the 4 → 8 → 16 org capacity story with real customers\n\n\nBuild Director into the AI-native backbone for the orgs that can least afford to lose theirs.\n\n\n\n",

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
Now I have a clear picture. Director for Good is NOT trying to be a point solution for finance. It's positioning itself as an **integrated backbone** covering:

1. Revenue & Relationships (fundraising/major gifts)
2. Runway & Finance (cash forecasts, budgets)
3. Ops & Compliance (payroll, filings, renewals)
4. Narratives & Reporting (board decks, funder reports)

The user is asking if this is too ambitious vs. focusing on just one area like finance.

Let me give them a strategic take on this.</details></think>

---

Looking at the deck, Director is tackling **4 domains simultaneously**: Revenue/Relationships, Finance, Ops/Compliance, and Narratives/Reporting.

**Short answer: No, but with caveats.**

The integrated approach actually makes sense for your specific beachhead—here's why:

## Why Integrated Works for You

1. **Your ICP is "founder doing everything alone"** — A finance-only tool doesn't solve their problem. They need relief across the board, not another point solution to manage.

2. **The value prop IS the integration** — "One pane of glass" is the differentiation. Bloomerang, QuickBooks, Monday, Notion separately = more cognitive load, not less.

3. **Data flows between domains** — Finance informs runway → runway informs funder narratives → narratives feed board decks. Siloed? You lose the compounding.

4. **Forward-deployed human bridges the gap** — You're not shipping pure software. The FDD + agents model lets you be "broad but shallow" on automation while humans handle edge cases. This is how Palantir and Rippling got away with massive surface area early.

## Where It Gets Risky

- **Engineering surface area** — 4 integrations (email, calendar, accounting, CRM) × 4 agents is a lot for one founding engineer
- **Messaging** — Investors may ding you for "boiling the ocean." You'll need tight answers on why you're not just doing finance-first
- **Proving value** — Harder to measure "backbone" than "we cut your close time by 50%"

## My Take

Keep the integrated vision, but **sequence ruthlessly in execution**:
- Month 0–3: Finance + Runway agent (easiest to demo, clearest ROI)
- Month 3–6: Ops/Compliance (builds trust)
- Month 6–12: Major Gifts + Narratives (relationship-dependent, takes longer to prove)

The deck already hints at this with the Pod model—you're selling human capacity first, agents second. That's the right order. The breadth is a feature, not a bug, *as long as you deliver depth through the FDD*.

---

_**User (2025-12-09 10:50Z)**_

What if we prototype by using off-the-shelf software from other companies that are doing this? Like there are startups that do finance, startups that do ops, startups that do gifts, startups that do marketing, and our team could basically operate all of those behind the scenes as an unscalable demonstration. 

---

_**Agent (model claude-4.5-opus-high-thinking, mode Ask)**_

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
The user is asking about a "Wizard of Oz" / concierge MVP approach — use existing SaaS tools behind the scenes, have the Director team operate them, and present a unified experience to the nonprofit customer. This is a classic lean startup validation technique.

Let me think through the pros/cons and give a strategic take.</details></think>

---

This is the **concierge MVP / "Wizard of Oz"** approach — and it's actually the smart play for your stage. Here's why it works and where to watch out:

## Why This Is Right

1. **Proves the value prop before building** — You're testing "do nonprofits pay for integrated backbone?" not "can we build 4 AI agents?" Those are different questions.

2. **Matches your Pod model anyway** — You're already selling FDD + Finance Director. Those humans can operate Bloomerang + QBO + Notion + whatever while you learn what actually matters.

3. **Reveals what to automate** — After 3–6 months of manual ops across 4 orgs, you'll know:
   - Which tasks are 80% of the FDD's time (automate first)
   - Which integrations are essential vs. nice-to-have
   - Where the data actually lives vs. where you thought it lived

4. **Lower burn, faster to market** — No engineering hire needed immediately. You and the FDD can onboard orgs next month.

5. **Defensible moat comes later** — Rippling, Gusto, even Palantir started with heavy services. The software crystallizes from the services.

## Practical Stack to Steal

| Domain | Tool | Why |
|--------|------|-----|
| Finance | QBO + Ramp or Mercury | Nonprofits already use these |
| Ops/Compliance | Notion or Monday | Playbook checklists, task tracking |
| Major Gifts | Bloomerang or even Airtable | Relationship mapping, pipeline |
| Narratives | Google Docs + Gamma or Canva | Board decks, reports |
| Unified view | Notion dashboard or simple Next.js page | Your "Director OS" facade |

## What to Watch

- **Don't hide it too hard** — Customers knowing you're "hand-crafting" early actually builds trust. "We're learning your workflows before we automate."

- **Track time religiously** — Log every task the FDD does. This becomes your agent spec and your unit economics model.

- **Cap at 4 orgs** — Beyond that, the manual approach breaks and you learn nothing new. Time to build.

- **Beware vendor lock-in** — If a customer is already on Salesforce NPSP, don't force them to Bloomerang. Your value is the integration layer, not the tools.

## Pitch Framing

To investors: *"We're running a forward-deployed prototype with real customers using best-in-class tools. We're capturing every workflow to build the AI agents that replace 80% of that manual work. This is how we de-risk the product before heavy engineering investment."*

This is basically the Levels Health / Pilot / Clipboard Health playbook. Services-wrapped-as-software → pure software once you've learned enough.

**TL;DR:** Yes, do this. It's not a compromise — it's the right sequencing.

_**User (2025-12-09 10:50Z)**_

Should this be a deck slide? 

---

_**Agent (model claude-4.5-opus-high-thinking, mode Ask)**_

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
The user is asking if the "Wizard of Oz" / concierge MVP approach using off-the-shelf tools should be included as a slide in their investor deck.

This is a strategic question about pitch deck design. Let me think about the pros and cons of including this.</details></think>

---

**Yes, but position it carefully.**

## Why Include It

- Shows **operational sophistication** — You're not naive about build vs. buy timing
- Answers the "how do you do this with 4 people?" objection before they ask
- Demonstrates **capital efficiency** — Not burning cash on eng before product-market fit
- Signals you understand the **services-to-software** playbook (investors love this pattern)

## Where to Put It

Either:
1. **Fold it into the existing "Director Pod" slide** — Add a line like "Year 1: Pod operates best-in-class tools. Year 2+: Agents automate what we've learned."
2. **New slide after "Director OS"** — Call it something like "How We Get There" or "Operational Approach"

## How to Frame It

**Don't say:** "We're using other people's software"

**Do say:** "We start services-heavy to learn workflows, then encode them into agents"

Something like:

---

### Slide: "Phase 1 – Learn Before We Build"

**We operate best-in-class tools behind a unified experience.**

- Finance: QuickBooks / Ramp
- Relationships: Bloomerang / Airtable  
- Ops: Notion playbooks
- Narratives: Google Docs + templates

**Why this works:**
- Onboard customers in weeks, not months
- Every task logged → becomes agent training data
- Capital-efficient: prove demand before heavy eng investment

**Transition to Director OS:** Once we've run 4 orgs for 6 months, we know exactly what to automate.

---

## When to Skip It

If you're pitching investors who are **deeply technical** and want to see proprietary tech moats early, this slide might raise "where's the defensibility?" questions. In that case, keep it verbal — mention it in the Q&A when they ask "how do you scale?"

For most seed investors though? This shows maturity and de-risks the bet.

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
The user is asking about the landscape for major gifts / donor relationship management software specifically for nonprofits. They want to know if there's a strong existing solution, or if this is a gap worth building into.

Let me think about what I know about this space:

1. **Traditional CRMs for nonprofits:**
- Salesforce NPSP (Nonprofit Success Pack) - powerful but complex, expensive, needs admin
- Bloomerang - simpler, good for small-mid nonprofits, more donor retention focused
- Little Green Light - budget option
- Neon CRM - mid-market
- Blackbaud (Raiser's Edge) - enterprise, legacy, expensive

2. **Major gifts specifically:**
- This is typically a module within larger CRMs, not standalone
- The "relationship intelligence" / "moves management" piece is usually manual
- EverTrue - does this for higher ed advancement
- Gravyty - AI for fundraising, but more about automating outreach
- Windfall - wealth screening / prospect research
- DonorSearch - wealth screening
- iWave - prospect research

3. **The gap:**
- Most tools are either:
  - Full CRMs that are overkill and require dedicated staff
  - Point solutions for wealth screening / prospect research
  - Not specifically designed around the "major gifts officer" workflow
- The relationship mapping + next-best-action + meeting prep workflow is largely manual
- AI-native major gifts tools are nascent

The user's instinct is probably right - major gifts is underserved by AI-native solutions specifically designed for the relationship-heavy, high-touch work of cultivating major donors. The existing tools are either legacy CRMs or point solutions for research, not the full workflow.

Let me do a web search to see if there are any hot new startups in this space I might be missing.</details></think>

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
Now I have a clearer picture. Let me think about this:

**Existing players:**
1. **EverTrue** - Focused on higher ed advancement, major gifts, portfolio management. Strong product but targeting universities primarily.
2. **Gravyty** - AI-powered outreach, email drafts, donor prioritization. More general nonprofit but feels more like "AI for volume outreach" than deep relationship management.
3. **Blackbaud** - Legacy, enterprise, expensive, complex. Adding AI features but still fundamentally an old-school CRM.
4. **DonorSearch / Windfall / iWave** - Wealth screening / prospect research. Point solutions, not relationship management.
5. **Kindsight** - More analytics / intelligence layer.

**The gap I see:**
- EverTrue is heavily higher ed focused
- Gravyty is more about scaling outreach volume, not the high-touch major gifts workflow
- Nothing is really designed for the "founder doing everything alone" persona - someone who needs:
  - Relationship mapping that builds itself from email/calendar
  - Meeting prep that actually knows the context
  - Follow-up tracking without manual CRM logging
  - Board-ready reporting on the pipeline

The user's instinct is right - there isn't a hot AI-native major gifts tool designed for the small nonprofit founder. The tools are either:
1. Enterprise (Blackbaud) - overkill, expensive
2. Higher ed focused (EverTrue) - wrong ICP
3. Volume outreach (Gravyty) - wrong motion for major gifts
4. Wealth screening only (DonorSearch) - point solution

This is a legitimate gap. And it plays to the deck's "relationships first" philosophy.</details></think>

---

Your instinct is right. Here's the landscape:

## What Exists

| Tool | Focus | Why It's Not "It" |
|------|-------|-------------------|
| **EverTrue** | Major gifts for higher ed | Focused on universities, not small nonprofits. Enterprise pricing. |
| **Gravyty** | AI outreach at scale | More about email volume than deep relationship management. Better for annual fund than major gifts. |
| **Blackbaud / Raiser's Edge** | Legacy CRM | Complex, expensive, needs dedicated admin. Your ICP can't run this alone. |
| **DonorSearch / Windfall** | Wealth screening | Prospect research only. Not relationship management. |
| **Bloomerang** | Donor retention | Good for small orgs, but not AI-native. Basic pipeline tools. |

## The Gap

Nobody is doing **AI-native relationship intelligence for the solo founder**:

- Relationship map that **builds itself** from email + calendar (no manual logging)
- **Meeting prep briefs** generated automatically before donor calls
- **Next-best-action** suggestions based on relationship signals
- Follow-up tracking that doesn't require CRM discipline
- Funder-ready pipeline reports without the data entry

Gravyty is closest but it's really "AI writes your outreach emails at scale" — that's annual fund motion, not major gifts cultivation.

## Why Major Gifts Is the Right Build

1. **Differentiates immediately** — You're not competing with QBO or Notion
2. **Highest value to your ICP** — Revenue is existential for downshifted orgs
3. **Hardest to fake with off-the-shelf** — Finance/ops can use QBO+Notion. Relationship intelligence can't.
4. **Fits your "relationships first" philosophy** — The deck already argues this is the core
5. **Data moat potential** — Email/calendar integrations + relationship graphs = defensible over time

## Suggested Stack

| Domain | Approach |
|--------|----------|
| **Major Gifts** | Build (your core product) |
| **Finance** | QBO + Ramp (off-the-shelf) |
| **Ops** | Notion playbooks (off-the-shelf) |
| **Narratives** | Google Docs + templates (off-the-shelf, automate later) |

This gives you one thing to demo that's yours, while the F
